title: About US
text:
The Kenyan Community in Scotland (KCS) is a vibrant, welcoming network dedicated to connecting, supporting, and empowering Kenyans living across Scotland.
Founded with the vision of fostering a strong, inclusive community, we aim to celebrate our rich Kenyan heritage while promoting integration, collaboration, and success within Scottish society.

title: A Fantastic Afternoon at Our Networking Mixer
text:
On 14 January 2024, the Kenyan Community in Scotland hosted a memorable Networking Mixer at The Foot of The Walk - JD Wetherspoon in Edinburgh. The afternoon was filled with energy, laughter, and meaningful conversations, bringing together a vibrant group of Kenyan professionals and friends.
A huge thank you to everyone who made time to attend. It was heartwarming to see so many familiar faces and meet new members of our growing community. The positive atmosphere reflected the strength and unity of Kenyans living in Scotland.




Lively Networking Sessions: Attendees engaged in dynamic discussions, exchanging ideas, career experiences, and professional insights across diverse industries including healthcare, IT, education, business, and the arts.
Sharing Life in Edinburgh: Many shared personal journeys about settling and thriving in Edinburgh, offering invaluable advice to newcomers.
Strengthening Community Bonds: Friendships were rekindled and new relationships were formed, reinforcing the importance of staying connected and supporting each other.
Youth and Family Engagement: It was also wonderful to see younger members of the community present, adding to the joyful and inclusive spirit of the day.





Our heartfelt appreciation goes to our venue, The Foot of The Walk - JD Wetherspoon, for providing a welcoming, comfortable, and relaxed environment. The excellent service and cozy setting contributed immensely to the success of the event.




This mixer was more than just an event; it was a reminder of the strength that lies in community. It highlighted our shared experiences, our aspirations, and the endless possibilities that collaboration brings.
We are excited about the future and are already planning more events to continue building a strong, supportive, and thriving Kenyan community network in Scotland.
Stay tuned for announcements on upcoming workshops, social events, and mentorship programs. Together, we are building a brighter future!

title: Join the Community
text:
Join the Kenyan Community in Scotland


library(shiny)
library(blastula)
library(glue)

# UI components
textInput("name", "Full Name:", placeholder = "Enter your full name")


Full Name:



textInput("email", "Email Address:", placeholder = "Enter your email address")


Email Address:



selectInput("interest", "Area of Interest:", choices = c("Networking", "Volunteering", "Events", "Sponsorship"))


Area of Interest:

Networking
Volunteering
Events
Sponsorship




actionButton("submit", "Submit")

Submit

textOutput("confirmation")



# Server-side logic
observeEvent(input$submit, {
  
  # Save data
  entry <- data.frame(
    name = input$name,
    email = input$email,
    interest = input$interest,
    timestamp = Sys.time()
  )
  
  if (!file.exists("community_signups.csv")) {
    write.csv(entry, "community_signups.csv", row.names = FALSE)
  } else {
    write.table(entry, "community_signups.csv", append = TRUE, sep = ",", col.names = FALSE, row.names = FALSE)
  }
  
  # Compose and send welcome email
  email <- compose_email(
    body = md(glue(
      "Hello {input$name},\n\n",
      "Thank you for joining the Kenyan Community in Scotland! üéâ\n\n",
      "We are excited to have you onboard.\n\n",
      "Stay tuned for upcoming events and activities!\n\n",
      "**Your selected area of interest:** {input$interest}\n\n",
      "Warm regards,\n\n",
      "Kenyan Community in Scotland Team"
    ))
  )
  
  smtp_send(
    email,
    from = "your-email@gmail.com",
    to = input$email,
    subject = "Welcome to the Kenyan Community in Scotland!",
    credentials = creds_key(id = "gmail")
  )
  
  # Confirmation message
  output$confirmation <- renderText({
    paste("Thank you,", input$name, "for joining! Please check your email. üìß")
  })
})

title: About US
text:
Our Mission

To create a platform where Kenyans in Scotland can connect, share, and grow together.
To promote cultural exchange, understanding, and appreciation between Kenyans and the wider Scottish community.
To support members through professional networking, mentorship, social events, and community service initiatives.

title: About US
text:
Our Vision
We envision a thriving Kenyan diaspora in Scotland that remains deeply connected to its roots while actively contributing to the social, cultural, and economic fabric of Scottish society.

title: About US
text:
What We Do

Community Events: Organizing cultural celebrations, professional mixers, workshops, and family gatherings.
Support and Advocacy: Offering resources, peer support, and advocacy for newcomers and long-term residents alike.
Partnerships: Collaborating with organizations, businesses, and institutions to create opportunities for our members.
Youth Engagement: Inspiring and mentoring the next generation of Kenyan-Scots.

title: About US
text:
Get Involved
Whether you are new to Scotland or have called it home for years, we invite you to join us.
Together, we can build a community that uplifts every member and celebrates the best of who we are.

title: Accessibility Commitment
text: The Kenyan Community in Scotland is committed to ensuring digital accessibility for all visitors to our website, including people with disabilities. We aim to make our website and content as accessible, inclusive, and user-friendly as possible.

title: Accessibility Commitment
text:
Our Commitment
We strive to:

Design content that is usable and readable for everyone.
Ensure that our website is navigable by keyboard and assistive technologies.
Provide text alternatives for non-text content, such as images.
Maintain high contrast between text and background colors.
Use clear and simple language wherever possible.

title: Accessibility Commitment
text:
Accessibility Features
Our website includes the following features:

Responsive design that works across desktop, tablet, and mobile devices.
Alternative text descriptions for images.
Accessible navigation menus.
Logical heading structures to assist screen readers.

title: Accessibility Commitment
text:
Ongoing Improvements
We recognize that accessibility is an ongoing effort. We are continuously reviewing and updating our website to improve usability for all users.
If you encounter any accessibility barriers or have suggestions for improvements, we welcome your feedback.

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text: On Saturday, 21st June 2025, members and friends of the Kenyan Community in Scotland came together for a stunning summer hike in the Glenshee region, conquering two magnificent Munros: Glas Tulaichean (1,051‚ÄØm / 3,448‚ÄØft) and C√†rn an R√¨gh (1,029‚ÄØm / 3,376‚ÄØft).

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text:
üåÑ The Day Unfolded
We departed Edinburgh at 6:00 AM, having assembled at Usher Hall with excitement and anticipation. After arriving around 8:00 AM at the Dalmunzie Hotel near Spittal of Glenshee, we began our 19 km circular hike under gradually clearing skies. The trail offered a mixture of gentle climbs and steeper sections through glens and ridges, revealing breathtaking Highland vistas.

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text:
üì∏ Highlights

Reaching the summit of Glas Tulaichean, where we were greeted with panoramic views stretching far across the Cairngorms.
Stopping for a well-deserved snacking in between summits.
Celebrating at the C√†rn an R√¨gh cairn with laughter, photos, and shared stories.
Encouraging and cheering each other through the final descent - team spirit at its finest.




Summit photo

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text:
üí¨ Reflections
For many participants, this was their first Munro experience ‚Äî and what a perfect introduction it was. From shared snacks and supportive steps to scenic breaks and collective encouragement, the hike embodied resilience, joy, and community.
This adventure reminded us of what lies at the heart of our community: togetherness, wellness, and exploration.

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text:

text:
üì∏ Journey Highlights

From Dalmunzie Hotel to Glas Tulaichean Summit

The journey begins at Dalmunzie: packs on, boots laced, spirits high.

Open terrain and distant peaks set the tone for the first Munro.

Final push to Glas Tulaichean with encouragement at every step.



Glas Tulaichean Summit Moments

A moment of triumph at 1,051 metres: smiles and cheers all around.

Resting at the top with Highland views all around.



Trek to C√†rn an R√¨gh

Descending Glas Tulaichean before the next climb begins.

The trail to C√†rn an R√¨gh opens wide as the next summit comes into view.



C√†rn an R√¨gh Summit Celebration

Second Munro conquered: a well-earned sense of achievement.

Feet tired but hearts full, we descended together through gentle paths and forested edges.

title: A Fantastic Afternoon at Our Networking Mixer
text:
On 14 January 2024, the Kenyan Community in Scotland hosted a memorable Networking Mixer at The Foot of The Walk - JD Wetherspoon in Edinburgh. The afternoon was filled with energy, laughter, and meaningful conversations, bringing together a vibrant group of Kenyan professionals and friends.
A huge thank you to everyone who made time to attend. It was heartwarming to see so many familiar faces and meet new members of our growing community. The positive atmosphere reflected the strength and unity of Kenyans living in Scotland.




Lively Networking Sessions: Attendees engaged in dynamic discussions, exchanging ideas, career experiences, and professional insights across diverse industries including healthcare, IT, education, business, and the arts.
Sharing Life in Edinburgh: Many shared personal journeys about settling and thriving in Edinburgh, offering invaluable advice to newcomers.
Strengthening Community Bonds: Friendships were rekindled and new relationships were formed, reinforcing the importance of staying connected and supporting each other.
Youth and Family Engagement: It was also wonderful to see younger members of the community present, adding to the joyful and inclusive spirit of the day.





Our heartfelt appreciation goes to our venue, The Foot of The Walk - JD Wetherspoon, for providing a welcoming, comfortable, and relaxed environment. The excellent service and cozy setting contributed immensely to the success of the event.




This mixer was more than just an event; it was a reminder of the strength that lies in community. It highlighted our shared experiences, our aspirations, and the endless possibilities that collaboration brings.
We are excited about the future and are already planning more events to continue building a strong, supportive, and thriving Kenyan community network in Scotland.
Stay tuned for announcements on upcoming workshops, social events, and mentorship programs. Together, we are building a brighter future!

title: Cheering On Team Kenya at the World Athletics Indoor Championships in Glasgow
text:
On Saturday, 2 March 2024, members of the Kenyan Community in Scotland gathered in Glasgow to attend the World Athletics Indoor Championships 2024, showing support and solidarity with Team Kenya at the Emirates Arena. It was a celebration of excellence, pride, and unity.
 The SSE Hydro and SEC Armadillo en route to the event
We started the day travelling through iconic Glasgow landmarks, eventually arriving at the venue, which buzzed with anticipation and flags from every corner of the world.
 Crowds approaching Emirates Arena

title: A Fantastic Afternoon at Our Networking Mixer
text:
On 14 January 2024, the Kenyan Community in Scotland hosted a memorable Networking Mixer at The Foot of The Walk - JD Wetherspoon in Edinburgh. The afternoon was filled with energy, laughter, and meaningful conversations, bringing together a vibrant group of Kenyan professionals and friends.
A huge thank you to everyone who made time to attend. It was heartwarming to see so many familiar faces and meet new members of our growing community. The positive atmosphere reflected the strength and unity of Kenyans living in Scotland.

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text: On Saturday, 21st June 2025, members and friends of the Kenyan Community in Scotland came together for a stunning summer hike in the Glenshee region, conquering two magnificent Munros: Glas Tulaichean (1,051‚ÄØm / 3,448‚ÄØft) and C√†rn an R√¨gh (1,029‚ÄØm / 3,376‚ÄØft).

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text:
üåÑ The Day Unfolded
We departed Edinburgh at 6:00 AM, having assembled at Usher Hall with excitement and anticipation. After arriving around 8:00 AM at the Dalmunzie Hotel near Spittal of Glenshee, we began our 19 km circular hike under gradually clearing skies. The trail offered a mixture of gentle climbs and steeper sections through glens and ridges, revealing breathtaking Highland vistas.

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text:
üì∏ Journey Highlights

From Dalmunzie Hotel to Glas Tulaichean Summit

The journey begins at Dalmunzie: packs on, boots laced, spirits high.

Open terrain and distant peaks set the tone for the first Munro.

Final push to Glas Tulaichean with encouragement at every step.



Glas Tulaichean Summit Moments

A moment of triumph at 1,051 metres: smiles and cheers all around.

Resting at the top with Highland views all around.



Trek to C√†rn an R√¨gh

Descending Glas Tulaichean before the next climb begins.

The trail to C√†rn an R√¨gh opens wide as the next summit comes into view.



C√†rn an R√¨gh Summit Celebration

Second Munro conquered: a well-earned sense of achievement.



Journey Back to Dalmunzie Hotel

A red tent dots the shore of Loch nan Eun: a quiet reminder of solitude amidst vast Highland beauty.

Feet tired but hearts full, we descended together through gentle paths and forested edges.
 With Dalmunzie in sight, conversations turned to food, photos, and future hikes.

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text:
üí¨ Reflections
For many participants, this was their first Munro experience, and what a perfect introduction it was. From shared snacks and supportive steps to scenic breaks and collective encouragement, the hike embodied resilience, joy, and community.
This adventure reminded us of what lies at the heart of our community: togetherness, wellness, and exploration.

title: Summiting Glas Tulaichean & C√†rn an R√¨gh: A Memorable Day in Glenshee
text:

A huge thanks to everyone who made this event successful, from organising transport and guiding the route to bringing contagious enthusiasm. You made it memorable!

‚ÄúI‚Äôm incredibly proud to represent my heritage while achieving this personal goal,‚Äù shared a graduate from the University of Edinburgh.

title: Linus Chirchir
text: Linus Chirchir is a passionate data scientist based in Edinburgh and a founding force behind the Kenyan Community in Scotland website. With over a decade of experience in health information systems, research, and analytics, Linus has dedicated his career to driving data-informed decisions that make a real-world impact.

title: Linus Chirchir
text:
üíº Professional Journey
Originally from Kenya, Linus worked at Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital where he managed integrated health information systems and supported research and analytics. After completing his MSc in Health Data Science at Swansea University, he joined the University of Edinburgh as a Health Data Analyst.
Currently, he works at Research Data Scotland (RDS) as a Data Analyst, where he prepares ADR Scotland datasets for integration into Scotland‚Äôs National Safe Haven. His work includes data cleaning, transformation, anonymisation, quality assessment, documentation, and collaboration with cross-functional teams.
He specialises in:

Synthetic data generation

Reproducible analytical pipelines (RAP)

GIS and public health data visualisation

Ethical AI and open science

R, SQL, Quarto, and Shiny app development

Linus finds purpose in applying technical expertise to real-world datasets that inform impactful research and policy.

title: Linus Chirchir
text:
üèôÔ∏è Life in Edinburgh
Since moving to Scotland, Linus has been deeply engaged in local and national community-building. Whether he‚Äôs coordinating Munro climbs, organising community mixers, or mentoring students, he fosters unity and wellness through action.
He believes in the power of shared experiences, storytelling, and open conversations - often over a hike or meal - to strengthen community bonds.

title: Linus Chirchir
text:
üí¨ In His Words

‚ÄúData is more than numbers, it‚Äôs about people, equity, and opportunity. And community gives our work meaning.‚Äù

title: Linus Chirchir
text:
üéì Education

MSc in Health Data Science, Swansea University

Master of Business Administration, United States International University ‚Äì Africa

Master of Information Systems, Kisii University

Bachelor of Business Management (Business Information Systems Management), Moi University

title: Linus Chirchir
text:
‚ú® Highlights & Reflections

Professional Highlight: Working with interdisciplinary teams at RDS to enable safe, ethical access to administrative data and support data-driven research.
Professional Challenge: Keeping pace with evolving best practices and technologies in large-scale data environments ‚Äî addressed through ongoing learning and collaboration.
Inspiration: Hans Rosling ‚Äî his data storytelling approach transformed Linus‚Äô view of analytics as a force for good.
Advice That Stuck: ‚ÄúStay curious and keep learning.‚Äù Change, as Heraclitus said, is the only constant ‚Äî and Linus embraces it as an opportunity to grow.
Fun Fact: His Mastermind subject would be Olympic Marathon Champions (1960‚Äì2024).

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text: Moving to Scotland from Kenya is an exciting journey, but it can also feel overwhelming at first. This guide walks you through the essential steps for settling in, with helpful resources, legal guidance, and local support links.

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text: Moving to Scotland from Kenya is an exciting journey, but it can also feel overwhelming at first. This guide walks you through the essential steps for settling in, with helpful resources, legal guidance, and local support links.

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text:
üìå 1. Visa Types and Application
Depending on your purpose, you‚Äôll apply for one of these visas:

Student Visa ‚Äì For those studying at a university or college.
Skilled Worker Visa ‚Äì For individuals with job offers in eligible occupations.
Family Visa ‚Äì For joining a spouse, child, or parent.
Visitor Visa ‚Äì Short-term stay (e.g.¬†tourism, business, or visiting family).
Graduate Visa ‚Äì For students who have completed their UK studies.

üîó Check which UK visa you need

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text:
üìÑ 2. Documents You‚Äôll Need
Ensure you have these key documents ready:

Valid passport

Visa confirmation (BRP or digital status)

Proof of accommodation in Scotland

NHS registration (after arrival)

TB test certificate (for long-term visas)

Police registration (if required)

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text:
üè† 3. Finding a Place to Live
Housing options include:

University accommodation (for students)

Private rentals ‚Äì via Rightmove, Zoopla, or Gumtree

Council or social housing (in special cases)

üìå Tip: Get a tenancy agreement and avoid cash-only landlords.

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text:
üè• 4. Healthcare and the NHS

Once you arrive, register with a local GP (doctor).
Access to healthcare is mostly free through the NHS, but some services like prescriptions may have fees.
Emergency: Dial 999

Non-emergency: Dial 111

üîó Find a local GP

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
text:
üíº 5. National Insurance Number
You‚Äôll need a National Insurance (NI) Number to work legally and pay taxes in the UK.
üîó Apply online for an NI Number

title: Immigration Guide for Newcomers
section: üìö 6. Settling In: What Else to Do
text:
üìö 6. Settling In: What Else to Do

Open a bank account: Use Monzo, Revolut, or traditional banks (Barclays, Lloyds, etc.)
Get a SIM card: Giffgaff, Lebara, or EE offer good deals for international calls
Know your rights: Especially if you‚Äôre a tenant or employee
Attend local orientation events: Check our Events

text:

You don‚Äôt have to do this alone. Join other Kenyans in Scotland:

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text: Healthcare in Scotland is free at the point of use through the NHS (National Health Service) - as long as you‚Äôve paid the Immigration Health Surcharge (IHS) as part of your visa application. This guide helps you navigate NHS Scotland services, register with a doctor, and know what to do in case of emergencies.

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text: Healthcare in Scotland is free at the point of use through the NHS (National Health Service) - as long as you‚Äôve paid the Immigration Health Surcharge (IHS) as part of your visa application. This guide helps you navigate NHS Scotland services, register with a doctor, and know what to do in case of emergencies.

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üß≠ 1. NHS Scotland Basics

NHS Scotland provides healthcare to all residents, including international newcomers who have paid the IHS.
You don‚Äôt pay for hospital care or GP visits.
You may pay a small charge for prescriptions or dental treatment.
Services are based on clinical need ‚Äî not your immigration status, as long as you‚Äôre eligible.

üîó Learn about NHS Scotland

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
ü©∫ 2. Registering with a GP
A General Practitioner (GP) is your first contact for non-emergency medical issues.

üìå Steps to register:

Find a GP practice near your home
üîó Find a GP practice
Call or visit the practice to request registration
Complete a registration form (can be done online or in person)
Provide ID (e.g.¬†passport, BRP) and proof of address (e.g.¬†tenancy agreement)

Once registered, you can: - Book GP appointments
- Get referrals to specialists
- Request repeat prescriptions
- Access mental health support
üìå Tip: Register early ‚Äî don‚Äôt wait until you‚Äôre unwell.

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üöë 3. Emergencies & Urgent Care

üÜò Life-threatening emergency?
Dial 999 for an ambulance, fire, or police.


üò∑ Not an emergency, but need urgent advice?
Dial 111 to speak to NHS 24, available 24/7.
Other urgent services: - Minor injuries units (for cuts, sprains, burns)
- Walk-in centres (in some cities)
- Out-of-hours GP services

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üíä 4. Medicines & Prescriptions

Prescriptions are free in Scotland.
Your GP will give you a prescription, which you take to a pharmacy (‚Äúchemist‚Äù).
Most large supermarkets (e.g.¬†Tesco, Asda) and high street chains (e.g.¬†Boots) have pharmacies.

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üò¨ 5. Dental & Eye Care

Dental care is not always free ‚Äî but it‚Äôs partially covered by the NHS.
You must register with an NHS dentist (some waiting lists may apply).
Eye tests are free every 2 years for residents in Scotland.
Opticians can refer you to hospital eye specialists if needed.

üîó Find a dentist
üîó Find an optician

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üß† 6. Mental Health Support
Mental health is taken seriously in Scotland. Services include:

Counselling via GP referral

Crisis lines and walk-in support

University mental health support (for students)

Community mental health services

Helpful links: - üîó Breathing Space Scotland
- üîó Samaritans ‚Äì call 116 123 any time, free
- üîó NHS Mental Health

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üë∂üèΩ 7. Family & Child Healthcare
Children under 16 receive free:

Vaccinations

School nurse visits

Dental checkups

Vision and hearing screening

New parents can access Health Visitors ‚Äî nurses who support families after childbirth.

title: Healthcare Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üßæ 8. Healthcare Rights & Protection

If you‚Äôve paid the IHS, you‚Äôre entitled to most NHS services during your stay.
You can choose a male or female GP.
Your data is confidential and protected by law.
Emergency services are always free, regardless of immigration status.

üìÑ 2. Documents You Need
Most banks require:

title: Banking Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
üîÑ 5. Sending & Receiving Money

title: Banking Guide for Kenyans in Scotland
text:
